 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed results-
based loan to India for the Strengthening Comprehensive Primary Health Care in Urban Areas 
Program  under  Pradhan Mantri  Atmanirbhar  Swasth  Bharat  Yojana.  The  report  also describes 
the proposed administration of technical assistance (TA) to be provided by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for Strengthening Capacity for Comprehensive Primary Health Care in Urban 
Areas, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me 
by the Board, approve the administration of the TA. 
 
2. 
The  Government  of  India  launched  the  Ayushman  Bharat  (the  Healthy  India  Initiative) 
Health and Wellness Centres (AB-HWC) in 2018 to improve access to comprehensive primary 
health care (CPHC) as an important strategy to achieve universal health coverage. In 2020, the 
coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  revealed  gaps  in  the  health  system,  so  the 
government announced the Pradhan Mantri Atmanirbhar Swasth Bharat Yojana (PM-ASBY) to 
strengthen public health systems to prepare for future pandemics and other emergencies. The 
proposed  results-based  lending  (RBL)  program will  assist the  government  in implementing  the 
AB-HWC and the PM-ASBY to strengthen primary health care in the urban areas of 13 selected 
states, and improve the urban population’s access to quality CPHC services.1 The RBL program 
target  beneficiaries  are  more  than  256 million  urban  dwellers,  including  51  million  urban  slum 
dwellers, especially the poor and vulnerable. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

Strategic Context 

 
A. 
 
3. 
India is one of the fast-growing large economies, with average growth of more than 6.7% 
from 2015 to 2019. The COVID-19 pandemic hit India’s economy hard—it contracted 23.9% in 
April–June 2020 because of the strict lockdown from late March to late May, and is projected to 
contract 9.0% in FY2021.2 The recovery may take longer if the pandemic is prolonged. About 70 
million  people  are  likely  to  be  pushed  into  extreme  poverty. 3 COVID-19  and  the  associated 
lockdown disrupted many routine and essential health services, undermining progress made on 
several health goals, such as maternal and infant health, tuberculosis and malaria treatment, and 
noncommunicable  diseases  (NCDs). 4  The  negative  mental  and  physical  health  impacts  of 
COVID-19, especially on vulnerable populations such as the urban migrant population and the 
elderly, will require longer-term health system responses. 
 
4. 
Current health status. From 1990 to 2017, India has seen substantial improvements in 
basic health indicators: life expectancy increased by 8.9 years to 67.8 for men and by 9.8 years 
to 70.2 for women. Maternal deaths per 100,000 live births declined from 408 to 160 in the same 
period.  The  greatest  achievement  has  been  the  reduction  of  under-five  mortality—from  111  to 
42 deaths per 1,000 live births. Tuberculosis declined by 29% and malaria incidence fell by 76%.5

Despite these achievements, India still accounts for 27% of TB and 4% of malaria cases in the 
world,6 and  has  the  third  largest  number  of  people  living  with  HIV.  It  also  faces  the  spread  of 
vector-borne  diseases  such  as  dengue  and  chikungunya.7 For  COVID-19,  India  has  reported 
more than 8.2 million confirmed cases, the second highest number after the United States as of 
2 November 2020.8 Despite the countrywide lockdown for more than 50 days from 25 March 2020 
and increased testing capacity (more than 1.5 million samples per day) to detect and isolate cases, 
COVID-19 cases are still increasing at an alarming rate. In addition, the demographic transition 
caused by increased life expectancy and changing lifestyles from rapid urbanization have led to 
a rise in NCDs. Cardiovascular diseases, respiratory diseases, and diabetes are major NCDs in 
India  that  kill  about  4  million  Indians  annually,  and  most  of  these  deaths  are  premature.9 This 
epidemiological  transition  leads  to  more  NCD  patients  with  disabilities,  which  poses  a  heavy 
financial  burden on  the health  system  and  affected  households.  Given the ongoing  COVID-19 
pandemic,  people  with  underlying  conditions,  particularly  NCDs,  are  also  at  increased  risk  of 
mortality during hospitalization.  
 
5. 
Urban health issues. In 2018, 461 million people or one-third of the Indian population 
were  living  in  cities,  which  is  the  second  largest  urban  population  in  the  world. 10 The  urban 
population  is  growing  rapidly,  and  by  2050  will  reach  877  million—almost  two-thirds  of  India’s 
population.11 Urban  populations  grew  faster  than  most  cities’  capacity  to  provide  basic  social 
services for all. Despite the common perception of easier access to health services in urban areas 
because of the large presence of private sector providers, health indicators of the urban poor are 
often comparable to or worse than those of the rural population. Full immunization among children 
aged 12–23 months is 57.7% for the urban poor compared with 61.3% for the rural population. 
Anemic children comprise 62.7% of the urban poor compared with 59.5% of the rural population. 
Most  urban  poor  women  do  not  seek  preventive  health  measures:  among  urban  poor  women 
aged  15–49  years,  only  20.0%  have  undergone  cervical  examinations,  9.3%  have  had  breast 
examinations, and 10.3% have received oral cavity examinations.12 The NCD burden is higher in 
urban areas, and the urban poor are particularly vulnerable to communicable and vector-borne 
diseases because of congested and poor living and health conditions. The risk of the spread of 
COVID-19 is 1.09 times higher in urban areas and 1.89 times higher in urban slums compared 
with rural areas based on the results of the first sero-survey conducted nationwide.13 More than 
one-third (35%) of all COVID-19 cases in India are concentrated in 20 cities or districts.14 
 
6.

dominate in urban areas. However, a large number of urban poor cannot access these services 
because  of  the  possibility  of  incurring  high  out-of-pocket  expenditures.  Drugs  and  diagnostic 
services make up 75% of out-of-pocket expenditures, which could be avoided if services were

7. 
Achievements and remaining gaps in urban public primary health care system. To 
address  the  large  gaps  in  urban  primary  health  care,  especially  for  the  poor  and  vulnerable 
populations, the government launched the National Urban Health Mission (NUHM) in 2013 as part 
of  the  National  Health  Mission  (NHM).  By  2019,  the  NUHM  had  established  more  than  4,500 
functional urban primary health centers (UPHCs) across India, significantly improving the urban 
population’s  access  to  maternal  and  child  health  care;  and  implemented  key  mechanisms  for 
urban health system governance and management.19 UPHCs have also played a crucial role in 
the COVID-19 response through surveillance, contact tracing, and test referrals. Overall, primary 
health care in India prioritizes a narrow range of services such as reproductive and child health 
services and selected communicable diseases. Currently, even a well-functioning primary health 
center  provides  limited services  that cater  to  less  than  15%  of  all morbidities for  which  people 
seek  health  care.20 For  other  morbidities,  people  use  local  private  care  providers,  distant  and 
crowded district hospitals, or government medical college hospitals. Investment in primary health 
care  is  cost-effective  and  can  reduce  overall  health  costs. 21  The  public  sector  has  also 
collaborated with the private sector in selected aspects of primary health care delivery, such as 
contracting in of specialist services, mobile medical units for improved outreach, and biomedical 
waste management. To strengthen private sector engagement, some states have contracted out 
the  entire  management  and  service  provision  of  primary  health  service  centers  to  the  private 
sector, usually nonprofit entities. The UPHCs need further improvement in infrastructure, human 
resources, and the availability of diagnostics and drugs. Outreach services also face challenges—
from  a  high  attrition  rate  of  community  health  workers,  inadequate  community  organizations, 
unreached pockets of vulnerable populations, and poor health-seeking behavior of the urban poor. 
Gaps  in  the  health  system  have  become  even  more  apparent  during  the  pandemic,  where

Government  initiatives.  The  National  Health  Policy  (2017)  emphasized  CPHC  as  an 
important strategy to achieve universal health coverage and committed two-thirds of the health 
budget  to  primary  health  care.23 In  addition  to  the  services  already  provided,  CPHC  includes

transforming  existing  primary  health  centers  into  HWCs  under  AB-HWC  as  a  vehicle  to 
operationalize  CPHC.  HWCs  will  offer  a  range  of  services  including  reproductive,  maternal, 
neonatal,  and  child  health  care;  adolescent  care;  the  management  of  national  communicable 
disease  programs;  general  outpatient  and  minor  ailments  care;  screening,  prevention,  control, 
and management  of  NCDs;  common  ophthalmic,  ear,  nose,  and  throat  care;  basic  oral  health 
care; elderly and palliative care; emergency medical services, including burns and trauma; and 
screening and basic management of mental health illnesses.

Program Rationale 

B. 
 
10. 
AB-HWC and the PM-ASBY to achieve the goal of CPHC in urban areas by improving equitable 
access to quality primary health services among the urban population. It is aligned with the country 
partnership  strategy  pillar  2:  providing  inclusive  access  to  social  services  by  providing  better 
services  for  the  urban  poor. 26 It  also  aligns  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  operational  priorities: 
(i) addressing remaining  poverty  and reducing  inequalities,  (ii)  accelerating  progress  in gender 
equality,  (iii) making  cities  more  livable,  and  (iv)  strengthening  governance  and  institutional 
capacity. The program is included in ADB’s India country operations business plan, 2021–2023.27 
 
11. 
Lessons. ADB has supported the NUHM since 2015 and recently provided support for 
India’s COVID-19 response.28 The lessons from the NUHM support, according to the Independent 
Evaluation  Department,  include  the  following:  (i)  outcome-level  disbursement-linked  indicators 
(DLIs) need to be within the direct control of the program, (ii) meaningful gender targets should 
be  set,  and  (iii)  independent  verification  should  be  used.29 The  RBL  program  will  incorporate 
lessons from the NUHM implementation and the COVID-19 response, such as (i) capacity building 
of  lower  performing  states  through  cross-learning  and  need-based  programs  rather  than 
spreading  efforts  thinly  over  the  country;  (ii)  strengthening  state-level  planning  for  CPHC  by 
closely  involving  state  and  substate  administrators  for  convergence  with other  urban  services, 
especially leveraging the experience of the COVID-19 response where a whole-of-government 
approach  has  been  adopted;  (iii) continuously  fostering  innovations  and  partnerships  with  the 
private  sector  through  DLIs;  (iv) strengthening  outreach  services  for  unreached  pockets  of 
vulnerable populations; and (v) leveraging information technology for evidence-based planning, 
effective service delivery, safer and more efficient training, and emergency responses. 
 
12. 
Results-based  lending.  The  RBL  modality  is  suitable  since  (i)  RBL  incentivizes 
stakeholders to adopt new areas such as NCDs and better client orientation, while strengthening 
existing systems using robust DLIs for change management and strengthening of systems and 
institutions;  (ii)  the  government  programs  have  a  well-defined  scope,  expected  results, 
expenditure framework, financing plan, and accompanying institutions and systems; (iii) a large

Program Technical Assessments 

 
A. 
 
The RBL program’s soundness was assessed based on its relevance and adequacy. The 
27. 
program is highly relevant to India’s universal health coverage agenda as well as sustainable and 
inclusive urban development. It will improve the health and well-being of the urban population, 
especially  the  poor  and  the  vulnerable,  providing  equitable  access  to  a  wider  range  of  quality 
health services. The constraints on the cost-effectiveness of primary health care, disproportionate 
benefits  to  the  poor  and  vulnerable  from  free  services,  and  health  emergency  preparedness, 
justify public provision of essential health services. In addition, the RBL program aims to facilitate 
partnerships with private health service providers  to improve service coverage and availability, 
and to ensure speedy expansion leveraging the large private sector presence in urban areas. The 
RBL program will strengthen convergence with other urban services, building on the experience 
of India’s COVID-19 response. 
 
The RBL program design and implementation arrangements are sound, building on NHM 
28. 
mechanisms  and  previous  RBL  program  experience.  The  results  framework  is  well  designed, 
following a health systems approach. The DLIs are critical indicators for achieving overall program 
results, sequenced to incentivize good performance. The expenditure framework and financing 
plan  are  robust.  The  sustainability  of  the  results  will  be  ensured  through  gender-responsive 
institutional capacity development and the development of a state-level road map for CPHC. The 
economic  analysis  shows  that  the  positive  effects  of  reduced  out-of-pocket  expenses  and 
increased productivity outweigh the program’s economic costs. The estimated economic rate of 
return of 13.1% indicates that the program is economically viable. 
 
29. 
The RBL program is categorized gender equity as a theme. It has a strong gender and 
pro-poor focus. In addition to a wider range of services made available for the urban poor, the 
RBL program includes DLIs for improved outreach services and frontline health workers’ capacity 
to support and facilitate access to services and health-seeking behaviors among the poor and the 
vulnerable, especially women and girls in urban areas. The RBL program includes specific actions 
and targets that will benefit women, such as (i) HWCs offering screening for cervical cancer and 
breast cancer (PAP); (ii) outreach services that address gender-based violence issues (DLI 6[i]); 
(iii) employment for 40% women at the new urban health technical division (DLI 8 [i]); and (iv) a 
section on gender-responsive service provision in the revised CPHC guidelines, as well as state 
road  maps  for  CPHC  in  urban  areas  (DLI  8  [i]  and  [ii]).  Accredited  social  health  activists  and 
Mahila Arogya Samitis (community women’s groups), who are 90% women, will also benefit from 
the  trainings  on  infectious  disease  response.  The  expanded  service  package  includes  mental 
health screening and support, which will be important to address the psychological impact of a 
prolonged COVID-19 pandemic and the consequent socioeconomic hardships.
